quizSrc.term: What characterises an audience that has been mentally persuaded by your message? Select all that apply.
quizSrc.definition: They generate more positive thoughts than negative thoughts; They have accepted your argument

quizSrc.term: What behavioural cues would signal that the audience has been persuaded by your message? Select all that apply.
quizSrc.definition: They would display enthusiasm in their gestures and body language; They are likely to ask 'how' questions

quizSrc.term: Why is Petty and Cacioppo's model of persuasion so influential? Select all that apply.
quizSrc.definition: It specifies situations when an audience is likely to engage with the message; It argues that the audience is actively judging your presentation

quizSrc.term: Why is persuasive communication challenging? Select only one response.
quizSrc.definition: Because you have to understand the needs of the audience

quizSrc.term: You have a difficult colleague who is attacking you and others in your meeting. Should you:
quizSrc.definition: Reason with the person explaining that their behaviour is not helpful to getting the results you're after.

quizSrc.term: You lose a major client. When explaining what has happened to your leadership team you:
quizSrc.definition: Determine whether they are a client you want to keep or not and seek out options to repair the relationship; Analyse what happened, take responsibility, seek more learning and refocus on who is your ideal client and how to get more of them.

quizSrc.term: In a meeting, your colleague has a different point of view to you. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Find out why the person believes what they do and negotiate a solution.

quizSrc.term: A colleague gets promoted over you and you don't think they should have been promoted. Every time something goes well, they claim responsibility. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Reflect on what it is the other person has that you want. Then communicate to your superiors what you want without shame, blame or attack; Let the boss know you want to be promoted. Then every time you succeed, let your boss informally know.

quizSrc.term: You are with a client and you find out what is important to them. Then you make them an offer based on what they've told you. They don't look convinced. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Assume you haven't found out clearly enough what they want and go back to questioning them; Realise they're not the ideal client for you and thank them for their time.

quizSrc.term: You are triggered in a meeting and start to feel frustrated. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Take time out and when you feel calm assess what happened and why, then have the conversations you need; Assess what you value, see which ones are flexible and whether your environment fits your values which are non-negotiable; Check in with yourself, see what's coming up and ask yourself what you need in that moment.
